dict.string: Remotely Identifying Temporal Risk for Falls
Consent to join the Developer Health Research Study.
Now you will create a passcode to identify yourself to the app and protect access to information you've entered.
This step concludes the onboarding and consent process of the GaitMate app. Next up, you will see main app functionality.
Please try again in five minutes.
This app will read step count, distance, and accelerometer data from your phone. The data is used to predict the fall risk.

Use this text to provide an explanation to your app participants about what electronic health records (EHR) you intend to collect from the Health app and why. This sample will read all available records (for which permission is granted).
Sign in using your Apple ID is fast and easy, and Apple will not track any of your activities.
We need to confirm your email address and send you a copy of the consent you just signed.
Are you sure you want to withdraw?
Withdrawing from the study will reset the app to the state it was in prior to you originally joining the study.
Thank you for your contribution to this study. We are sorry that you could not continue. The app will now close.

GaitMate is a research app from Stanford Hospital that was created in cooperation with the Stanford Byers Center for Biodesign. By facilitating at home functional mobility assessment, it helps estimate an individual‚Äôs risk of falling, and informs strategies to reduce this risk.

GaitMate is a research app from Stanford Hospital that was created in cooperation with the Stanford Byers Center for Biodesign. By facilitating at home functional mobility assessment, it helps estimate an individual‚Äôs risk of falling, and informs strategies to reduce this risk.
This app collects data that can help estimate an individual‚Äôs risk of falling and informs strategies to reduce this risk. This includes monthly self-report and mobility assessments.
This app collects data that can help estimate an individual‚Äôs risk of falling and informs strategies to reduce this risk. This includes monthly self-report and mobility assessments.
Your data is stored securely without personally identifiable information.
Your data is stored securely without personally identifiable information.
The data gathered is used for research purposes at Stanford Hospital.
The data gathered is used for research purposes at Stanford Hospital.

When first using the app you will be asked to fill out an onboarding survey, which takes about 10 minutes. The app also asks you to perform a monthly mobility assessment and short survey, which also takes about 10 minutes.

When first using the app you will be asked to provide some basic demographic and health information. Filling out the onboarding survey takes about 10 minutes. The app also asks you to perform a monthly mobility assessment and short survey, which also takes about 10 minutes.

The app contains two surveys. The first onboardning survey will ask you to provide basic demographic and health information. The second survey is a short monthly check-in to see if anything has changed since the last time we asked you.

The app contains two surveys. The first onboardning survey will ask you to provide basic demographic and health information. The second survey is a short monthly check-in to see if anything has changed since the last time we asked you.

The main task the app is asking you to do is a walking task. You will be asked to put your cell phone into a pouch around your hips, stand up and walk 10 feet back and forth and sit down again. That's it!

The main task the app is asking you to do is a walking task. You will be asked to put your cell phone into a pouch around your hips, stand up and walk 10 feet back and forth and sit down again. That's it!
If you want to withdraw from the study, please notify your contact person at Stanford Hospital.
If you want to withdraw from the study, please notify your contact person at Stanford Hospital.
